basics.name: Igor Sadalski
basics.summary: Machine Learning Scientist at Somite.ai. MSc in Computer Science (Machine Learning) from Imperial College London. Research interests in foundational models, transformers, and genomic AI.

work.summary: Architected spot-instance, SLURM-based training infrastructure integrating FSDP, mixed precision, and Flash Attention across tens of MI325X/H200 GPUs, enabling scalable, multi-node training of billion-parameter transformers on proprietary data. Led curation of genomic data and engineered distributed data pipeline to process terabytes of data, achieving nearly 3x speedup. Designed agentic AI pipelines and investigated scaling laws for transformer and VAE-based models on genomic data.
highlights: Architected spot-instance, SLURM-based training infrastructure integrating FSDP, mixed precision, and Flash Attention across tens of MI325X/H200 GPUs, enabling scalable, multi-node training of billion-parameter transformers
Led curation of genomic data scraped from the internet and engineered distributed data pipeline to process terabytes of data, achieving nearly 3x speedup
Designed agentic AI pipelines to automate data curation and new agentic approaches for advancing cell annotation

Investigated scaling laws for transformer and VAE-based models on genomic data and benchmarked encoding strategies, generating insights leading to work presented at ICML Workshop '25 and submitted to Nature Biotechnology
Joined as the 6th employee at a Harvard-MIT academic spinoff developing foundation models for the human cell ($60M+ in funding)

leadership.summary: Founded and led team of 20+ students building software for an autonomous car, coordinated development across perception, planning, and control, and raced on the Silverstone F1 track.
Co-led operations and workshops for Imperial's largest academic club (1000+ members).

research.summary: Investigated techniques for performing sub-quadratic attention; based on this work, designed a long-context time series transformer-based model. The model was later used to proactively route shuttle buses around Harvard campus.
Designed conditional variational autoencoders and diffusion models to obtain data-driven error estimates from flight data. These models were later used to improve drone flight performance and safety.
Sped up model predictive controller running on robotic hardware by rewriting matrix operations using optimized C++ library.
